Audio tape recording of interview with Percy Hole of Guildford, by Walter Thelwall, taken in Frensham Ward, Royal Surrey County Hospital, Guildford.

Mr Hole was an apprentice at Dennis Bros, Guildford, and later at Weyside Engineering, Farnham Road, Guildford.

Mr Thelwall was also employed by Dennis Bros, in 1940.

Topics of the conversation as they arise include: 

Percy's father's employment at No 7 Shop, Dennis Bros.  He made 'sprags' for lorries and spliced wire cables for barrage balloons during the first World War.

Recollection of the petrol-driven shunting engine used on the factory site, which Percy rode on as a boy [connecting to the Southern Railway].

Percy's apprenticeship at Dennis.  He began as office boy in various offices (cost office, drawing office, staff, publicity), then transferred to the factory.  He was soon made redundant: women, then apprentices were laid off by Dennis in 1920

Percy's apprenticeship was transferred to Weyside Engineering in Farnham Road, Guildford.

Percy's recollection of one of the Dennis managers, for whom Percy brought a new bottle of Whisky daily

Recollection of the running of the firm, which was bankrupt in 1912 [before being floated in 1913].  'German' money went into the company.  Interest in lorries only came with the war.

Percy's recollection of a Dennis 3 ton lorry used by Percy with his boss Harold Puttock (who left in 1926): the gears were perfect after 300 thousand miles.

Percy's final task at Dennis in 1920, which was to seal 750 letters of redundancy, including one addressed to his father.

Recollections by Percy Hole and Walter Thelwall of fellow employees at Dennis: Bill/James Jolly, Billy Greaves, Joe Taylor, Shackleton, Warrener, and 'Old Flo'; also man who worked on the roller mills, and Percy's sister, who worked on the mills, 1915-1919, doing shackles (semi-automatic mills were still in use in 1940); Mr Thelwall recalls Frank Brown, who came to Dennis as an apprentice, worked on turning machines, and left Dennis after 33 years to become an inspector at Weyside Engineering [see -/4 below].

Percy's recollections of an accident at No 3 Shop, when the Dennis' chauffeur took the casualty in Mrs Dennis' Dennis car

Mr Thelwall's recollection of a near accident at No 7 Shop during World War II, when the hair of one of the girls was caught in a machine spindle.

The 8 girls were sent from Tottenham.

Percy's recollections of serving tea to the staff; recollections of tea shops of Guildford: Queens Cakes, Onslow Street, and Hicks Bakers.  Percy describes the breakdown of Hicks' Ford van when he replaced the engine oil with 'doughnut oil'.

Recollection of the 'Dennis Tatler', which was a magazine run by a Mr Reed, given free to employees.  The Athletic Club and Dance Club and concert party events were reported.

Recollection of Percy and the new office boy shooting at bulbs.  The new boy was gassed, as the bulbs were the gas-filled variety.

The steering on Dennis vehicles is praised.

Percy's recollection of having been the first to drive the Dennis 36 seater charabanc on road, when he was 14.  He had his photograph taken by Dennis publicity.

Percy's recollection of criticising the Dennis Stork, without realising he was speaking to the designer, Mr Milne.  Recollections of the various makes of cars driven by Dennis staff.

Duration: 42 mins approx

Audio tape recording of interview with Frank Brown of Guildford, by Walter Thelwall, taken at Brown's home in Agraria Road.

Mr Brown worked at Dennis for 33 years, then became an inspector for Weyside Engineering [see interview with Percy Hole -/1 above].

Topics of conversation as they arise include: 

Recollections of Frank's apprenticeship: he went to Guildford Technical College on a 2 year scholarship, and was then found an apprenticeship.  He chose Dennis from a choice of 'three or four', and started work in Aug 1917.

He did stints in various parts of the factory, beginning with grinding.  The apprenticeship finished in 1921, when he left as an 'improver'.  he returned to Dennis after 2 years.

Recollections of automation of the machines.  Frank had charge of 2 machines.  Mr Thelwall operated a semi-automatic mill.

Recollections of the ability of foreman Lance Edwards, and the skill required to operate machinery: even the experienced operator was injured on the automatic turret lathe.

New machines were acquired when Dennis moved to Woodbridge Hill.

Recollections of the General Strike of 1926.  Dennis men were to be dismissed, but the partners wanted the master gearcutter Rapson back, so they took everyone.

Frank went to London as a special constable, but the strike was over when he arrived.  He claims that 'nobody's heart was in it'.

Frank's recollections of what he describes as the obstructiveness of the unions, when he was a mechanical inspector [at Weyside Engineering].

Recollections of the Dennis subsidy engine, which was slow but long-lasting.  The development of the Big 4 and the Light 6, when 7-8 draughtsmen studied a German vehicle.

Mr Thelwall's recollection of  working on a machine known as the 'white elephant', later a cam shaft wheel.

The recording ends abruptly.  The sound quality of the original recording is very poor.

43 mins approx

Audio tape recording of interview with Mr Robinson, an engineer at Dickensen and Burne of Guildford, who served in the Royal Flying Corps in World War I.

The conversation begins with reference to Mr Robinson's posting to Alexandria [Egypt], then recalls his apprenticeship, and earlier training, before returning to his war time experiences.

He was apprenticed with Dickensen and Burne, engineers, whose workshops were in Leapale Lane, Guildford.  The railings ('bars') in front of the workshop 'are still there'.  Their foundry was where the [Yvonne Arnaud] theatre now is, where iron moulding and casting (using various metals) took place.  They made high speed steam engines for use on ships, boat reversing gears and 'all sorts', including work for Dennis Bros, Guildford.  Robinson worked as a pattern maker.

The firm was later the 'Hays Brothers', one of whom worked in the drawing office, the other as an engineer.

Mr Robinson volunteered for the Queen's Regiment and began his training as a private.  But when those with engineering experience were asked to stand forward, he did and was 'glad to do something more interesting'. Describes being tested at a site in Cobham for his ability to 'make a dovetail'.  He was quickly approved, and sent for training in flying at Beverley [Yorkshire] racecourse (touchdowns are described).  'There was no real flying corps' at that time.

He was sent to Alexandria, and eventually 'up the line' to Jerusalem, after being sent to Mesopotamia 'by mistake'.  He met T E Lawrence [of Arabia] and General Edmund Allenby [later Field Marshal Viscount Allenby of Megiddo] (described).

Describes preparing aircraft and fitting bombs.

Mr Robinson flew an RE8 12 cylinder.

When he was being shown how to fly it, half the wing fell off.  He once hit a bell tent while taking off, and a man was killed: neither he nor his observer, a 2nd lieutenant knew what had happened.

26 mins approx

Tape recording of an interview between the 7th Earl of Onslow and Brian Wilson in which Lord Onslow describes his views on the enactment in November 1999 of the Bill for the abolition of the rights of hereditary peers to sit in the House of Lords.

Lord Onslow opens by summarising the history of the House of Lords from origin in the middle ages to the reforms occasioned by the Reform Act, 1832, the Home Rule Bill, 1896, and the Parliament Act, 1911 (1&2 Geo.V, ch.13).

He briefly sets out his opinion of how the reform should have been organised before going on to describe his part in the events leading to the enactment of the Bill and the creation of a new 'Stage 1' House of Lords, pending a final decision as to the constitution of the second chamber.

He concludes by stating his belief that the current House of Lords [which includes 92 hereditary peers from all parties who were selected by the outgoing peers] has been granted new legitimacy by the reforms and is thus, he feels, more powerful.

Duration: c.45 mins.

Column27: The Ottershaw Survey, a photographic, written and topographical survey, was compiled by Hannah Lane, secretary of the Ottershaw Society, on behalf of the Society.\r\n\r\nThe project began as a photographic survey, to record a 'snapshot' of the village as it was in 1995, for which a grant was awarded by Rural Action.  This work became the basis for a more extensive undertaking, covering the development of the village of Ottershaw (and including Stonehill, Foxhills, Botleys and Silverlands) from c.1800, including oral history and documentation of a variety of collected records.  Mrs Lane continued to collect information and further material after depositing the original Survey: her revised text of 2018  has replaced the original version and first and second  revisions (2008 and 2012), and additional photographs and papers have been inserted in the series.  In 2018, Mrs Lane decided 'it was a suitable time to end my research - the end of an era',  since under the new Local Plan for Runnymede Borough, the village of Ottershaw and its environs, to date designated Green Belt, were set to change beyond recognition with the creation of large areas of housing and new roads.  The last edition of the text records those areas forecast to be principally affected.

Column27: The Farnham Decorative and Fine Arts Society (DFAS) Group of Garden Recorders was formed on 3 October 2002 to carry out a survey of the garden at The Garden Cottage, Crooksbury House, Tilford, for the Surrey Gardens Trust.  The project began with an introductory workshop in garden recording, initially looking at maps and other source material, followed by a site visit to the garden.  One aspect of the Group's brief was to establish if Gertrude Jekyll (1843-1932), garden designer of Godalming, had had any direct input into the garden.\r\n\r\nThe survey was completed in 2006 and a report produced by the Group of Garden Recorders on the garden's history, 1889-2006.  The Group of Garden Recorders comprised Judithe M Blacklaw, Jenny Cameron Smail, Cynthia Gallagher and Vicky Jackson.  As of October 2007, The Garden Cottage is still being used as a private residence.  Farnham DFAS is a member society of NADFAS.

GYPSY ROMA TRAVELLER HISTORY MONTH: RECORDED INTERVIEWS
Column8: All interviews were conducted by Rib Davis of the Lightbox, Woking, at Bourne Hall Museum, Ewell. The interviews cover the personal upbringing of the individuals concerned, the practical impact of their culture on their everyday lives, and then go on to explore how gypsy/traveller culture has changed with the continuing influence of integration.
Column26: Deposited by Rib Davis, Oral History Officer of the Lightbox, Woking, in June 2008.  Transcripts of the interviews were added to this collection in December 2019.
Column27: The first Gypsy Roma Traveller History month was held in June 2008. The nationwide project was directed towards schools, libraries, museums and cinemas with the aim of educating a wider audience about traveller history and culture. The initiative started in 2003 in the London Borough of Brent and spread across the country following public support and funding from the Department of Children, Schools and Families. As part of the activities and to support its own oral history project, Woking Lightbox recorded a series of interviews with Surrey travellers at Bourne Hall Museum, Ewell, in June 2008.\r\n\r\nGypsy Roma Traveller History Month was part of a wider initiative, based at Surrey History Centre headed 'Roads to Your Past'. Funded jointly between the European Union and South East Museum Library and Archive Council, the initiative aimed to encourage greater access to local heritage centres by traveller communities and promote a wider appreciation of gypsy/Romany culture. The relevance of the project is probably best summarized by Len Smith, traveller, who says 'Museums, libraries and archives could be powerful places for us if we can make them accessible. You bring two people in, and they tell four people and the four people tell another four people and it can start giving gypsies and travellers a bit more pride - we have a private pride in our culture – we need a public pride; we need a public face to our pride' (from Private Past, Public Future: see related records below).
Column29: A report entitled 'Private Past, Public Future', can be viewed on the Surrey History Centre website.  The report, compiled by Jake Bowers, assesses how traveller communities perceive the preservation of their culture by local heritage centres.

MARY WONDRAUSCH (1923-2016), POTTER, PAINTER AND WRITER OF COMPTON: PAPERS
Column8: The collection includes papers relating to Mary Wondrausch's potteries at Farncombe and Compton; exhibitions of her work; correspondence, writing and research for her books on slipware and Brickfields, her house at Compton, and articles on pottery, food and textiles; sketch books of designs and drawings, and photographs, 1960-2017.  There are also collected items including deeds of property in Godalming, 1677-1747, and plans of a house at Ockford for Thomas Cooper, 1870.
Column21: Presented by Mrs Claudia Nockolds, daughter of Mary Wondrausch, in April 2017.
Column22: Mary Wondrausch was born Mary Angela Lambert in Battersea on 17 December 1923, the daughter of Harold Lambert and Margaret (nee Montgomery).  She trained at Kingston School of Art and in the Second World War was in the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps as a cook.  She was originally a painter working principally in collage when she lived in Chelsea and was a member of the Women's International Art Club.  She was married three times, the third time in 1954 to the Polish architect Witold Wondrausch, with whom she had three children.  In 1955 she moved to Brickfields, Compton.  During the 1960s she was an art teacher at Barrow Hills School, Witley.  She studied pottery part-time at Farnham College of Art in 1969.  In 1975 she started Wharf Pottery, initially in Godalming and then at 55 St John's Street, Farncombe, before selling the premises and converting the stables at Brickfields into a pottery in 1984.  She specialised in the production of slipware and commemorative plates.  During the 1980s she travelled in France, Germany and Hungary studying and working with country potters.  In 1986 she published 'Mary Wondrausch on Slipware' (A & C Black).  She was a Member and Fellow of the Craft Potters Association.  Her pottery and paintings were exhibited widely and examples of her work are held in local and national museums and private collections.  She also researched and wrote on food, pottery food containers and kitchen equipment.  She was the author of the article in the 'Oxford Dictionary of National Biography' on Dorothy Rosaman Hartley (1893-1985), social historian, illustrator and author, who was best known as the author of the book 'Food In England' (1954).  Mary Wondrausch was awarded the OBE in 2000 for services to the arts.  She published a book on her life at Brickfields in 2004.  She died on 26 December 2016.

Column23: Jennifer Louis was born Jennifer Statham in Surbiton in 1932 and spent her early life in Esher, Capel and Westhumble.  After graduating from Edinburgh University in 1953, Jennifer obtained a post looking after the daughter of the British naval attache at the embassy in Moscow, Russia.  While in Russia she met the Soviet journalist Victor Louis (1928-1992), and after a brief time back at Westhumble, returned to the Soviet Union, where she married him in 1958.  They lived in Moscow for many years, Victor Louis providing information for western news outlets and with Jennifer writing a number of guidebooks on Moscow and the Soviet Union and the directory 'Information Moscow' for foreigners in Moscow.  Victor Louis died in 1992, but Jennifer Louis did not finally return permanently to Westhumble until 2004.\r\n\r\nThe oral history recordings capture much detail about Jennifer Louis' extraordinary and varied life.

'THE LIVING AND THE DEAD: EXPLORING MINORITY BURIAL GROUNDS IN BROOKWOOD CEMETERY, SURREY': PROJECT PAPERS AND ORAL HISTORY RECORDINGS
Column8: Oral history recordings deposited by Dr Ole Jensen, project manager, and other papers transferred from Surrey Heritage Service, in March 2023.  These records are the outcome of the National Lottery Heritage Fund-funded project 'The Living and the Dead: Exploring minority burial grounds in Brookwood Cemetery, Surrey'. The project was implemented over a two-year period from September 2020 to September 2022. It was led by Woking Asian Business Forum, working with Brookwood Cemetery, Surrey History Centre, The Lightbox and Brookwood Cemetery Society.\r\n\r\nUnknown to most, Brookwood Cemetery (Surrey HER Park and Garden 3723) is host to the highest concentration of minority burial grounds in the UK. Apart from a wide range of Muslim burial grounds, dating from 1884, these include the first Zoroastrian burial ground established in Europe, in 1862. These burial grounds constitute an important part of Brookwood Cemetery, and they represent a unique cultural heritage that has so far remained undocumented. The aim of the project was to collect information about the burial grounds and make this information available to the public.  Various strands of the project included conducting oral history interviews with a range of people associated with the Cemetery, making a film about the minority burial grounds in the Cemetery, and recording data about minority burials from the burial registers.

SURREY HEATHLAND PROJECT: TAPED INTERVIEWS AND SUMMARIES OF REMINISCENCES OF PEOPLE RESIDING ON SURREY HEATHLAND
Column21: Transferred by Jenny Page and Marcus Tully, Surrey Heathland Project, in September 2009.
Column22:
In 1988 Surrey County Council and the Nature Conservancy Council published 'A Strategy for Surrey Heathland'. The study highlighted that Surrey had lost over 85% of its heathland since the late 18th century.

As a result, in 1989 the Heathland Countryside Management Project (later to become Surrey Heathland Project) was set up to help stop the decline. The project initially carried out practical work with help from committed volunteers, using hand tools to clear scrub and control bracken on hundreds of hectares of heathland. However it became clear that this method could not keep pace with the rolling tide of scrub invasion. To make best use of limited resources, the project increasingly used chainsaw operators and contractors with machinery.

In 2002 the Surrey Heathland Project began to manage a 5 year programme of heathland restoration work called Surrey's Last Wilderness on behalf of a partnership of 13 organisations. This was part of a large-scale national scheme with £1 million funding from the Heritage Lottery Fund. Surrey's Last Wilderness achieved over 1,000 hectares of heathland management and restoration, and introduced conservation grazing to manage 900 hectares of heathland.

Part of the project included raising awareness of heathland and to promoting its value. The reminiscences of people who live and work on Surrey heathlands proved a valuable contribution to the project demonstrating how important and sustaining areas of heathland are to local communities.

Column8: Each interviewee is assigned a separate series within this collection, with a folder title giving name and date of interview.  Each folder contains the following sub-folders: 'Documents', for administrative material relating to the interview, and earlier versions of track summaries where available; 'Public' for copies of material such as photographs, documents and artefacts referred to during the interview, mp3 format copies of the recordings, tagging files in Excel format, and the final version of the track summary; 'Recordings' for files in Raw and Wav format; and 'Tagging' for those recordings tagged using Audacity.  The data for each interviewee may lack one or more of the sub-folders.  The dates of each file are the date the digital file was last edited, and for the Raw and Wav recordings files, the date of the interview.  The date of interview is also given in the series title for each interviewee in the format (yyyy-mm-dd).

Title: Clark_Monica and Watson_Muriel 2019-08-12
Column8:
Interview of Monica Clark and Muriel Watson for Surrey in the Great War oral history project.

Subjects:
Second World War - Father was Ambulance Driver with 8th Army. Action at Anzio Beachhead and Monte Casino. Did not see him throughout (6 years) and when returned he was like a stranger to the children. He rarely spoke about his experience but clearly traumatised him as he would shout out in the middle of the night.  They had evacuees, children and some mothers. One thin baby without its mother.  2 Doodlebugs dropped nearby, fright causing one girl to fall downstairs. Left a crack down front of cottage.

Entertainment - Board games, radio, Just William.

Locale - Went to St John's Church, Windlesham, including Sunday School, but Monica confirmed at Chobham; Muriel not confirmed.  Grandparents in Sunningdale used to walk to Windlesham via the golf course.

Sport - Athletics at School and Lion Works Sports Day. Ascot Races. Grandfather take in bicycles to mind while at races.

Health - Family generally healthy. Girls had Yellow Jaundice; mum broke arm walking to Windlesham.  Mum avoided calling Doctor if possible due to cost. Glad when NHS arrived.
